p: Few studies reported the possible phytotoxic activity of M. pulegium EOs. Kimbaris and coworkers [ 35] reported that S. lycopersicum was significantly affected by EOs derived from two populations of Grecian M. pulegium: one rich in piperitone (96.5%) and another in pulegone (74.4%). In our study, only the EO from MPFIII inhibited the germination of S. lycopersicum seeds at 100 Âµg/mL, although piperitone or pulegone are the main constituents in all our samples, this probably because in the previous study authors used higher doses of EOs (0.4 and 0.2 mg/mL). Considering this, our EOs seemed to be more phytotoxic than Grecian M. pulegium EOs.
